Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Pareto-Optimized Heat Diffusion Protocol on Ollivier-Ricci Curvature Controlled Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
While there are a variety of throughput-optimal wireless network protocols, more challenging is the problem of making the protocol optimal relative to such conflicting objectives as queue occupancy (related to latency) and routing cost (related to power management), while holding throughput-optimality. The first step in that direction is the design of a protocol mimicking heat diffusion, as the celebrated Dirichlet principle of heat calculus already endows the routing with minimum routing cost property. The next step requires a significant departure from heat diffusion in order to make the protocol Pareto-optimal relative to routing cost and queue occupancy, while enforcing interference restrictions, link directionality and capacity. From this point onwards, the research effort will be conducted along two different lines of investigation. First, since the classical heat calculus had to be modified in a nontrivial way to make it an implementable wireless network protocol, there is a need to understand the ?heat equation? in the context of directed graphs, subject to interference restrictions and capacity constraints. Classical heat calculus involves the classical Laplacian, which is a linear operator, while here the central mathematical object of concern of this new "heat calculus" is a nonlinear Laplacian in the fluid limit, which describes the rate-level, rather than packet-level, behavior of the stochastic wireless network. The second line of investigation is dedicated to finding the network invariant that could anticipate the potential for large queue occupancy and/or large routing cost. We will develop the Ollivier-Ricci curvature as a computationally implementable network parameter inversely proportional to queue occupancy and routing cost, even under directionality and other network constraints. Also, the Ollivier-Ricci curvature will be investigated as a predictor of the size of the capacity region. Finally, the research will culminate with some Ricci flow technique to optimize the network for maximum Ollivier-Ricci curvature, hence attaining the largest capacity region.

The framework of this proposal is applicable to a wide family of stochastic problems with interdependent resources, where the resources are a collection of interdependent servers that can only be accessed under certain constraints, and the consumers are of random service time with asynchronous completion. This general model describes a wide variety of problems including queuing networks, product assembly systems, memory or processor managements, call centers, agent allocations, data switches, healthcare systems, and transmission planning or storage allocation in power systems just to name a few. Specifically, the research will strive to achieve cross-fertilization among this broad set of problems with classical thermodynamics and Ohm?s law in circuit theory that open a new way to analyze and optimize these complicated problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The original motivation of this research was to develop a new class of wireless network protocols, the so-called Heat Diffusion protocol. Wireless networks include such home/office applications as blue-tooth, WIFI, LAN, etc. However, wireless networks are also utilized for large scale data collections and such networks are usually referred to sensor networks. Applications include soil moisture analysis for agricultural purposes, oil and gas exploration, data collection in dangerous environments (nuclear, bacteriological, chemical or other contamination). The basic idea of the Heat Diffusion is to mimic nature by treating packets (the smallest unbreakable pieces of computer messages) as calories (the "quanta" of heat). The protocol moves packets (calories in the heat diffusion metaphor) from sources (hot spots) to destinations (cold areas) in the same matter as heat runs from a hot reservoir to a cold reservoir. The Heat Diffusion protocol was shown by computer simulation to outperform the more traditional Back-Pressure (BP) protocol. The problem is that computer simulations are no substitute for a formal proof. This has been popularized in the wake of the proof of Fermat theorem, where even though Fermat theorem was demonstrated to hold up to very large integers, computer simulations could never verify it for all integers and a formal proof, for no matter how large integers, was needed, and eventually crafted.  

In this work, we followed the same pattern and spent a considerable amount of time proving that our Heat Diffusion protocol is the best possible in terms of Pareto optimality. The proof of Fermat theorem was a laborious process, plagued by gaps in presumed proofs, followed by corrections of errors, until eventually an ironclad proof was developed by Andrew Wiles. We did not escape such “error-correction-of-error” process as several of our early proofs turned up to be wrong, until eventually the correct proof was found.

The Heat Diffusion protocol is meant to operate in many different environments, usually modeled as  graphs, consisting of nodes (individuals in social networks) and edges or branches (interaction or friendship  in social networks). Such graphs can greatly vary in their mathematical properties. Some graphs are easy to communicate on; some others are difficult to communicate on; among such "difficulties,"  the most relevant is congestion. Some highway architectures allow for smooth traffic flow, some others are prone to traffic jams. The need to define a metric quantifying how easy a graph is to communicate on, or how easily a graph transports entities, became pressing. Another major result of this research is that the Ollivier-Ricci curvature of the graph has appeared to be the correct metric. Not only is it applicable to wireless networks, but also has applications in the power grid, in computer architecture, in social networks (community detection), in finances, and last but not least in metabolic networks with applications to cancer research.
